title: 112_hr1123
content: The Act may be cited as the "TIFIA Expansion Act of 2011" and it pertains to TIFIA funding of qualified transit capital projects. The "TIFIA Expansion Act of 2011" amends the definition of Master Credit Agreement to include projects that reduce greenhouse gas emissions or alleviate congestion and receive up to 30% of funding from Federal sources. The "TIFIA Expansion Act of 2011" amends the definition of Master Credit Agreement to include projects that reduce greenhouse gas emissions or alleviate congestion and receive funding from Federal grant funds or chapter 53 of title 49, United States Code. The term 'master credit agreement' refers to an agreement between the Secretary and an obligor for a project that makes contingent commitments of secured loans or other Federal credit instruments at future dates, establishes amounts and terms, and identifies dedicated revenue sources. The TIFIA Expansion Act of 2011 amends the definition of Master Credit Agreement to include projects that reduce greenhouse gas emissions or alleviate congestion and receive funding from Federal grant funds or chapter 53 of title 49, United States Code. It identifies dedicated revenue sources for repayment of secured loans or Federal credit instruments and outlines obligations for funds after meeting all project requirements, including compliance with the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. Eligibility and eligible projected costs are also addressed in the amendments to title 23, United States Code. The TIFIA Expansion Act of 2011 expands the definition of Master Credit Agreement to include projects reducing greenhouse gas emissions or alleviating congestion with Federal grant funds. It establishes dedicated revenue sources for loan repayment and outlines obligations post-project completion, including compliance with NEPA. Amendments to title 23, United States Code address eligibility and projected costs for mega transportation projects exceeding $1 billion. Loan terms are adjusted, with the interest rate requirement increased to 49 percent. The Secretary has the authority to waive certain loan application requirements if the loan amount is less than 33% of project costs and secured by tax revenue. Amendments to title 23, United States Code increase the allowable percentage of lines of credit to 49%. Funding amounts for fiscal years 2011 through 2015 are adjusted, with unobligated balances addressed for secured loans. With respect to secured loans under chapter 6 of title 23, only unobligated balances from prior fiscal years can be used for Transportation Secretary's authority.
